Class actions are a critical tool to help workers, consumers, and victims who have been wronged. This bill eliminates this tool and dismantles the basic rights of Americans to pursue justice in the courts.  If this weren’t bad enough, the bill also attacks victims of asbestos. It lets companies shirk their responsibilities to victims of asbestos exposure by adding extra obstacles to victims who are already struggling to receive their just compensation. Adding insult to injury, this bill violates victims’ privacy by requiring the entities responsible for paying asbestos victims to release their sensitive personal information, including their names and medical histories. This bill does nothing to help victims of asbestos exposure suffering from serious health problems – instead, it re-victimizes them and invades their privacy.

It’s time for Fox in the Hen House Friday! This week’s feature is dedicated to the many foxes that are the driving force behind Trumpcare, the Republicans’ reckless quest to destroy the ACA and replace it with a tax break for millionaires and billionaires.  The bottom line is that Trumpcare is going to make you pay more for less. Trumpcare benefits individuals who are healthy, younger, and richer, and it hurts those who are older, in need of health care, and fighting to get by on fixed or limited incomes.  The Brookings Institute estimates that Trumpcare will increase the number of uninsured Americans by more than 15 million. AARP estimates that under Trumpcare, a 64-year-old making $15,000 a year would see an $8,400 hike in premiums plus copays. Yes, you read that right – Republicans want to charge seniors over half their total income for health care.  If you experience a gap in coverage - for example if you lose your job or change jobs – insurance companies will be allowed to charge you a 30 percent higher premium.Trumpcare also defunds Planned Parenthood, leaving 2.5 million Americans without their preferred provider.  This is a far cry from the “insurance for everybody” promise President Trump made during his telephone interview with The Washington Post just last month. And Speaker Ryan’s glowing references to Trumpcare as beneficial to women in his Wednesday PowerPoint presentation would be laughable if it weren’t for the fact that it does the exact opposite, gutting coverage and sending us back to the days when being a woman qualifies as a preexisting health condition.  But the President and Speaker Ryan aren’t the only sly foxes storming the health care hen house. During the House Energy and Commerce markup of the bill, Republican Congressman John Shimkus of Illinois asked why men should have to pay for prenatal care. Could Congressman Shimkus be unaware of the role that men play in making babies? Also, House Oversight & Government Reform Chairman Jason Chaffetz of Utah so helpfully noted that people have the choice to “invest” in their health care, saying, “Americans have choices and they’ve gotta make a choice. And so maybe rather than getting that new iPhone that they just love and they want to go spend hundreds of dollars on that, maybe they should invest in their own health care. They’ve gotta make those decisions themselves.” Reality check: The cost of a new iPhone, with no contract, is $670, while the median health care cost per capita is $10,345. So unless people are buying 15 iPhones each year, that is not going to help them save for their appendix removals or cholesterol medication.  It’s time to hold on to our chickens, because pretty soon the hen house will only have foxes.

On Earth Day, we honor and celebrate our beautiful planet. Whether you are a scientist marching today, a student cleaning up a beach or a concerned citizen planting a tree, we can all do our part to make a contribution. I would like to share with you the thoughts of the Republican Co-Chair of the first Earth Day in 1970, Pete McCloskey, a man I deeply respect and admire. He, along with Wisconsin Senator Gaylor Nelson and Dennis Hayes organized a the very first national day of environmental study that brought thousands of student and teachers to the streets and eventually gave birth to the environmental movement. The results affected every American. As Pete says in his essay, a Democratic Congress and a Republican President, Richard Nixon, passed landmark legislation on a bi-partisan basis. The Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, protection of Marine mammals, coastal zones, and The Endangered Species Act were enacted into law, with Nixon creating the Environmental Protection Agency. It is up to all of us to reignite this movement.                                         Earth Day, April 22, 1970              A Tribute to Senator Gaylord Nelson (D. Wisconsin) and                     Stanford Student Body President Denis Hayes       On entering Nebraska on the old Oregon Trail, one is greeted by a sign:   "Welcome to Nebraska.  Home of Arbor Day."   Arbor Day had been conceived by a Nebraska school teacher in 1874, with the idea that each school child should plant a seedling for Nebraska's rolling grasslands on April 22nd each year.  In time Arbor Day came to be celebrated in every U.S. state and in many countries around the world.   On some future day, a visitor to California on the road to Donner Pass or the Mojave Desert, may someday find a sign:  "Welcome to California.  Home of Earth Day."   The first Earth Day, April 22, 1970, was motivated by the love for California of Democratic Senator Gaylord Nelson of Wisconsin, who in his youth had attended San Jose State College and become familiar with Yosemite, Sequoia, Lassen and our National Parks and Monuments. He had backpacked on the John Muir Trail in the High Sierra and had come to love the mountainous wilderness, the redwood forests, deserts and sunny beaches of the Golden State.   Musing with a friend in San Francisco, one late afternoon watching a sunset over the Golden Gate Bridge, and thinking of the beauties of California, he said  You know, we ought to celebrate a day to honor the Earth."   The friend said, "Yes, and it ought to be bi-partisan."  Nelson replied:  "And it ought to be bicameral."   Nelson recruited the Stanford Student Body President, 21 year-old Denis Hayes to direct the effort, and asked the only reputed Republican environmentalist in the House to be his Co-Chair.  The head of the Conservation Foundation, Sid Howe, raised $100,000, and commencing in January, 1970, Hayes assembled a group of young people, average age 20 or less, to join him in Washington D.C., there to prepare for a national "day of environmental study."   Earth Day, April 22nd, a Sunday, was to be a day of contemplation of the need for clearer air, purer water, protection of our landscapes and wildlife, and the health of the oceans.   It was during the heat of student protest against the Viet Nam War, and the tragedy of Kent State would occur two weeks later, yet all across the nation, that afternoon of Sunday, April 22nd, students and teachers turned their attention to a national discussion of environmental issues.    But the young organizers of Earth Day were not through.   Recognizing the need to take their concerns to the level of actual policy, they held a single press conference, naming 12 Members of the House "The Dirty Dozen," and vowing their defeat at the polls. Few took them seriously.   But organize they did.  In the following primary elections, thousands of students assembled in Baltimore and Denver to turn out the vote in their targeted races;  The following day, the nation awoke to the astonishing news that the two Democrats on the list had both been defeated, by those thousands of students turning out unprecedented vote totals in what had been considered no-contest primaries.  The environmental movement was born.   This was followed by similar turnouts and similar results in the November elections for five of the ten Republicans of the Dirty Dozen.   The result was startling.  When Congress convened in January, 1971, with seven new Democrats, a new "pro-environment" majority in both parties in both the House and Senate had emerged.   And what happened?  Over the next four years, with a Democratic Congress and a Republican President, Richard Nixon, landmark legislation were passed on a bi-partisan basis.   The Clean Air Act, Clean Water Act, protection of Marine mammals, coastal zones, and The Endangered Species Act were enacted into law, with Nixon creating the Environmental Protection Agency.   Bi-partisan environmental cooperation lasted for 24 years, with four Republican and two Democratic Presidents.   Regrettably, those years of bi-partisan cooperation ended with the ascension of Newt Gingrich as Speaker of the House, in 1995. For the past 21 years, the Republican Party has abandoned the original principles of Theodore Roosevelt, Gifford Pinchot and environmental pioneers, and become a party opposed not only to environmental protections but dedicated to the removal of most of the environmental regulations of past Republican presidents. Ford, Reagan and George H.W. Bush.   Worse, today's Republicans have abandoned the ethic of preservation of wild places for the benefit of the public, instead pursuing the actual evisceration of regulatory protections of habitat and species, and further, the giving away, transfer, or sale of federal public lands.   With control of  both Houses of Congress and the White House firmly in the hands of Republicans, the next chance at achieving even a remote check on the intended destruction of the environment and the abandonment of the concept of delaying global warming by the Trump Administration and his Republican devotees in the Congress will be the 2018 elections.   And what better place for such defeats to occur than in California, the Golden State, where, led by Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy of Fresno,   Republican Members like Northern Californians McClintock, LaMalfa, Denham, Valadeo, and Nunes are already acting to end protection for rivers and wildlife habitat, together with an end to scientific research into global warming. They have already voted to permit the shooting of hibernating bears and their cubs from aircraft and the gassing of wolf pups in their dens in Alaskan wildlife refuges, and propose to cut the funding for the EPA, the Fish & Wildlife Service, and other science and environment-based agencies. They have devised and plan to pass legislation to deed federal lands over to states and private developers.    The Endangered Species Act is a primary target.   By this time next year, its protections and those of the EPA may be largely illusory.   Hopefully, a new generation of passionate students will rise up now and in 2018, perhaps naming and defeating a "Dirty Thirty," or even "Dirty Fifty" Members of the House, turning out to vote in record numbers,  and forcing Congress to re-establish balanced environmental protections and a return of efforts to slow, if not reverse, global warming. This would be a fitting tribute to Senator Nelson, Denis Hayes and the first Earth Day forty seven years ago.   Pete McCloskey Republican Co-Chair Earth Day, 1970

For several months, parishioners and students of St. Brendan Church & School in San Francisco have been studying the subject of global hunger. They wrote letters to me and to Leader Pelosi to express their concerns. I was in Washington, but yesterday those letters were delivered by students of the school, along with the Pastor, Parish Manager, and Principal to staff from both offices. For a week, the children collected all the food that wasn't eaten at lunch time, and they compared that to the amount of food needed by a hungry child. In another exercise, students were given tickets and were then offered the portion of a meal represented by the ticket. So, one student might receive 40% of a meal while another child might receive 2% of the same meal. This taught the students about the amount of food that we consume in the U.S. when compared with other nations.   In addition, parishioners heard homilies, read bulletin articles, and attended soup suppers during Lent to learn more about the problem. I commend the educators, parents, students, and parishioners of St. Brendan's for learning about this important topic, and for dedicating themselves to ending global hunger by 2030.

This week in Through the Legislative Looking Glass, House Republicans have pushed through the “Working Families Flexibility Act” (H.R. 1180), which is a fraud – it neither helps working families nor provides workplace flexibility.  This bill claims to give workers flexibility with their schedules, but what it really does is give employers a new excuse to avoid paying overtime. House Republicans state that this bill will allow employees to trade their overtime compensation for extra time off. In reality, it includes so many loopholes that employees might be robbed of their time-and-a-half overtime pay without the guarantee that they would ever be able to take comp time.  While Republicans shamefully passed this smoke-and-mirrors bill this afternoon, Democrats have provided real solutions. The “Healthy Families Act” (H.R. 1516) would provide workers with paid sick time off – 36% of the workforce, or 41 million U.S. workers, do not have paid sick leave. The “Family and Medical Insurance Leave (FAMILY) Act” (H.R. 947) would set up a paid family and medical leave insurance program. I am a proud cosponsor of both of these bills. Republicans need to stop looking for ways for employers to shirk their responsibilities at the expense of their employees, and instead commit themselves to passing real solutions to provide working families with the flexibility they need and deserve.

On today’s 52nd anniversary of Medicare and Medicaid, I’m calling on President Trump and Congressional Republicans to come to the table and work to improve the ACA rather than tearing it down with destructive legislation that will leave millions of hard-working Americans without the care they need to survive.  Medicare and Medicaid programs are lifelines for so many of my constituents, including Sascha from San Franscisco. Sascha is a quadriplegic with a speech disability as a result of cerebral palsy. She recently told me that when she was 3-years-old, a doctor told her young, single mother that Sascha would “never be able to do much of anything. [But] with a great deal of help from my mom and all the other people she calls my village, I was able to prove that doctor wrong. The support of Medicaid has been critical to my success.” Sascha relies on Medicaid for at-home and community-based care, including having an attendant to help her bathe, dress, go to work, and run errands. Her attendants have been a literal lifeline to the outside world and have enabled her to lead a full and productive life in her community, rather than languishing in an institution or nursing home.  Thanks to Medicaid, Sasha was able to attend UC Berkeley and she has since worked for many years providing disability awareness and resource programs to thousands of students in the Bay Area. Medicaid also saved her life, and her financial security, after she was diagnosed with lymphoma in 2013. Due to her disability, she suffered severe complications that resulted in a five month hospital stay. As Sascha said, “If there had been a cap on Medicaid, my family would have gone bankrupt … I could have just died. A Medicaid cap is a real ‘death panel.’”  Medicaid has also been critical to ensuring my constituent Marissa’s health. Marissa is a transgender woman living in South San Francisco, who for a year now has received her Hormone Replacement Therapy and vital medications through Medi-Cal.  Marissa told me, “I am absolutely shocked by the GOP and Trump's plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act and concerned for the well-being of myself and many others. Without access to affordable health care, I cannot continue treatment, and may have to detransition, which will destroy my physical and mental health. I urge you by any means necessary to keep the ACA in place, not just for me, but for the millions of Americans whose lives and livelihoods depend on it.” The only way forward for Sascha, Marissa, and all of America is for both parties to come together to fix the ACA and make it better for everyone.

The horrendous wild fires in the North Bay and Santa Cruz mountains have left physical and psychological scars that will take years to heal. To make matters worse, we now have scam artists who are trying to take advantage of this deadly tragedy and rip off fire victims. Please beware of scams and report anything that seems suspicious to FEMA, the Federal Emergency Management Agency. Here are some tips on how to avoid fraudulent phone calls and report them to FEMA:  State and federal recovery officials urge California residents to watch for and report any suspicious activity or potential fraud from scam artists, identity thieves and other criminals who may try to prey on vulnerable survivors of the October wildfires.  Common post-disaster fraud practices include:  •         Fake offers of state or federal aid: o   Beware if anyone claiming to be from the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) or the state visits, calls or emails asking for an applicant’s Social Security number, bank account number or other sensitive information. o   Avoid scam artists who promise a disaster grant and ask for cash deposits or advance payments in full. o   Know that federal workers do not solicit or accept money. FEMA and the U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) staff never charge applicants for disaster assistance, inspections or help in filling out applications. Do not give out information and report people claiming to be government workers to local police. o   Provide your Social Security number and banking information only when registering for FEMA assistance, either by calling 800-621-3362, TTY 800-462-7585, or going online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov or the smart phone FEMA App. If you use 711-Relay or Video Relay Services, call 800-621-3362. Operators are multilingual and calls are answered from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. seven days a week.   •         Phony housing inspectors: Owners/applicants may be especially vulnerable to phony housing inspectors claiming to represent FEMA or SBA. An applicant should always: o   Ask to see the inspector’s identification badge. All federal employees and contractors carry official, laminated photo identification. o   Inspectors also have each applicant’s nine-digit registration number. o   FEMA inspectors never require banking information.  It is important to note that FEMA housing inspectors verify damage, but do not hire or endorse specific contractors to fix homes or recommend repairs.  They do not determine your eligibility for assistance.   •         Fraudulent building contractors: When hiring a contractor, be sure to: o   Use licensed local contractors backed by reliable references.  o   Demand that contractors carry general liability insurance and worker’s compensation.  •         Bogus pleas for post-disaster donations: Unscrupulous solicitors may play on the sympathy for disaster survivors. Disaster aid solicitations may arrive by phone, email, letter or face-to-face visits. Verify legitimate solicitation: o   Ask for the charity’s exact name, street address, phone number, and Web address, then call the charity directly and confirm that the person asking for funds is an employee or volunteer. o   Don’t pay with cash. o   Request a receipt with the charity’s name, street address, phone number and Web address (if applicable).  Anyone with knowledge of fraud, waste or abuse may call the FEMA Disaster Fraud Hotline at 866-720-5721 or report it to the Federal Trade Commission at www.ftccompliantassistant.gov You may also send an email to DHSOIGHotline@dhs.gov

Happy Thanksgiving! I would like to share the recipe for a salad that I make every Thanksgiving.  Ingredients: 1 1/2 cups fresh cranberries 3 T. Sugar 1 cup toasted chopped pecans or walnuts 1/4 cup lime juice 2 t. Dijon mustard 3/4 t. Salt 2/3 to 1 cup olive oil 3 Granny Smith apples, cored and cut into bite-sized pieces 1/4 cup thinly sliced scallions Spring mix or similar greens 1 T. Finely grated lime rind Pomegranate seeds to sprinkle on top  Chop cranberries coarse with a stainless steel knife and toss them with sugar in a small bowl. let them stand, covered and chilled, for at least 1 hour or overnight.  In a large ceramic or glass bowl combine lime juice, mustard and salt. Add the olive oil in a stream, beating until it is well combined. Add apples, nuts and scallions. Toss the mixture, and let it marinate, covered and chilled, for at least 1 hour, but not more than 4 hours.  Plate the greens as a base, add the apple mixture followed with a dollop of cranberries, a sprinkle of pomegranate seeds and lime rind. Drizzle some of the marinade on the lettuce greens and serve!  6-8 servings

Yesterday, the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence marked up a reauthorization of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act Section 702. “Section 702,” as it’s called, is supposed to do exactly what its name promises: collect foreign intelligence from non-Americans located outside the United States. What this bill actually does is allow significant numbers of Americans to be improperly swept up in surveillance activities that the law says must not target Americans. This improperly obtained information has been used in court against Americans charged with crimes that have nothing to do with national security, with no warrants and without the required notifications to the defense.    This is far too serious of a matter to ram a renewal of these authorities with less than 36 hour notice through committee, leaving no time for real debate and discussion. I believe that Section 702 authorities are critical to our national security, and that there is a true balance to be struck between security and civil liberties. This bill fails to balance those concerns, and that is why I voted against it.

Five years ago today, the House of Representatives observed a moment of silence to honor the 20 6- and 7-year-old school children and six adults who were slaughtered in the Sandy Hook mass shooting. Since then, The House has held 39 identical moments of silence. Each time, I am struck by the hypocrisy of Members of Congress gathering to honor these lost innocent lives, and then failing to take any meaningful action to prevent future tragedies. Moments of silence are literally the least we can do. Instead of remaining silent, we must take meaningful action to end preventable deaths from gun violence. The families of the victims mourn in this silence every day. They speak out for sane gun violence prevention laws to a silent Congress. But Congress can and should act.  We can start by closing many of the loopholes that benefit the gun manufacturing industry and its lobbyists. The vast majority of Americans, even gun owners, support commonsense background checks. It is clear that assault weapons have no place in civilian hands. And it is past time that we lift the ban on gun violence research. As we honor those lost in Newtown today, let us recommit ourselves to passing common-sense gun safety solutions and end the silence.

Do you ever wonder how the rest of the country thinks? Join me for my next Conversation about America with sociologist and bestselling author Arlie Russell Hochschild. Professor Hochschild will discuss her latest book, Strangers in Their Own Land, with me and answer your questions. In Strangers in Their Own Land, Professor Hochschild takes readers on a thought-provoking journey from her liberal hometown Berkeley, California to Louisiana bayou country, a stronghold of the Tea Party and the conservative right. For five years she meets and gets to know people who strongly oppose many of her ideas and beliefs, but she still manages to find common ground with them about concerns that all Americans share: the desire for community, the embrace of family, and hopes for their children.
